wikipedia_page.main: Richard Neilson Lochhead (born 24 May 1969) is a Scottish National Party (SNP) politician who is Minister for Just Transition, Employment and Fair Work and has been the Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) for Moray since 2006. He was previously an MSP for North East Scotland 1999–2006 and served as the Cabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs, Food and Environment from 2007 to 2016, and the Minister for Further Education, Higher Education and Science from 2018 to 2021.

From the end of April 2021 into May 2021, Elgin was the epicentre of a resurgence of the Coronavirus in the Covid-19 pandemic. Moray as a whole had around four times the infection rate of Scotland. Despite the success of a vaccination programme reaching one million second doses in the country, with nearly a quarter of the adult population receiving both doses and over three-fifths having had their first dose, the vaccines that were approved (still largely Pfizer-BioNTech and AstraZeneca) required two doses and therefore many people were only partially protected. The vaccination programme still prioritised older age groups with invitations only starting to be sent out to those under 50 and there now started to be hospitalisations seen, including in younger age groups under 50.  As Moray, along with the rest of Scotland started to come out of a lockdown, for the first time with vaccinations present, the cases centred on the town started to rise and public health experts warned of "uncontrolled, sustained community transmission" of the virus. On 7 May 2021, it was revealed that Richard Lochhead, a minister in the Scottish Government who was, in the event, re-elected to the Scottish Parliament was unable to attend the count of the Moray constituency election as he was voluntarily self-isolating awaiting the results of a coronavirus test for a member of his family.

A by-election in the Moray constituency of the Scottish Parliament was held on 27 April 2006 following the death of the Scottish National Party (SNP) Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) Margaret Ewing on 21 March 2006, from breast cancer. The seat was successfully defended by the SNP's Richard Lochhead, increasing the majority over the Scottish Conservative Party by 1073 votes.

Richard Lochhead defended the seat for the Scottish National Party. An additional-member MSP for the North East Scotland electoral region since 1999, he had already been selected to contest the seat for the SNP at the 2007 Scottish Parliament election, beating the incumbent's sister-in-law, former MP Annabelle Ewing. He resigned his list seat to stand in the by-election.
